EmailTemplate.subject: Spring Data “Codd” release train GA
EmailTemplate.textOnly:
MARCH 2014 <https://spring.io/blog/2014/02/24/spring-data-release-train-codd-goes-ga> Spring Data "Codd" release train GA! Spring Data’s release train is getting more and more shiny new boxcars added! Team leads Oliver Gierke and Thomas Darimont are coordinating an impressive community of projects, all making coordinated releases, with more new projects on the way in the upcoming “Dijkstra” release. The “Codd” release offers relational access via JPA, noSQL stores like MongoDB and Neo4J, search providers like Solr, and technology like Data REST – all while kicking 260 bugs off the train. While more blogs are coming about the release, you can read about some of the new features <https://spring.io/blog/2014/02/07/what-s-new-in-spring-data-codd-rc1> in the RC1 release announcement blog. Go ahead, jump on the train and take the release for a spin! Learn More <http://spring.io/blog/2014/02/24/spring-data-release-train-codd-goes-ga> Give Your Data a REST with Spring Data REST Spring Data Codd is upon us. Spring Data has long featured the concept of a repository: a class that facilitates data-access. With Spring Data, defining such a class can be as easy as defining an interface! Did you know that, thanks to Spring Data REST, you can also transparently expose those services as a REST endpoint? Spring Data REST makes it dead simple to automatically get a REST interface that exposes the repository and its CRUD-style endpoints. Here's a working Spring Boot application that uses Spring Data JPA and Spring Data REST.
You can easily test out the service using curl, like this: curl http://localhost:8080/bookings -H"Accept: application/json". To build this application, I simply went to the Spring Initializr and chose JPA, Web, and REST Repositories, then chose Generate Maven Project. Finally, I added the H2 embedded database for rapid prototyping and an in-built DataSource bean: <dependency> <groupId>com.h2database</groupId> <artifactId>h2</artifactId> </dependency> Using the quick fix feature in Eclipse to type less The Java tooling in Eclipse provides a nice and simple way to help you typing less - using the quick-fix mechanism. You might be aware of that mechanism helping you fixing problems and errors, but it can do more for you. Imagine you would like to call a method that returns an object of a certain type and you would like to assign that to a new local variable - a fairly common task. Using the quick-fix mechanism in Eclipse, you don’t need to write down the type and the name of the local variable. Just call the method and press quick fix (Ctrl/Cmd-1): Select the “assign statement to new local variable” and you are done. Spring Framework 4 on Java 8 Spring has a track record of providing dedicated support for new Java generations in a timely fashion, and now it’s right about time to go Java 8: With Spring Framework 4.0, we're providing in-depth support for all relevant OpenJDK 8 features, including lambda expressions, JSR-310 Date and Time, parameter name discovery, and java.util.concurrent enhancements.
This talk will illustrate basic Spring Framework 4.0 concepts, and selected Java 8 features within Spring's programming model, exploring the impact on application architectures. Europe
